title: Code Deployment Freezes: Part 1
Ask HN: Launching niche service soon, looking for advice
text:
Hello All, Looking for some advice one launching a very niche product soon.

I already know it will save my clients time. Currently they manually import information from a spreadsheet into accounting software. This can take some of my clients a day to do as it is extremely tedious.

The best part is, once all the bugs and flow is worked out it can all be completely automated. Client would only need to set it up properly and then verify in their accounting software.

My current list of items to complete before launch: 1. Create videos on how to use it. 2. Documentation with links to the videos for each key step. 3. Maybe ask questions after first use to find out pricing before making it public. ... looking for more here.

What are some key steps I should take before launching to all my customers and market to outside my customer base.

I'm also struggling on how to price this value added service. It can make a days worth of work into minutes.

Not sure if I should price it based on actions, customers, or just general tiered pricing.

The service will launch with no pay window. You will use it once and after that it will ask you to pay before using it again.

Should I create a questionnaire for the beta users to find out a good base price?

Thank you

title: Why Subspace (an experimental, safer, simpler C++ standard library)
Ask HN: Anyone get anxious when they have nothing to do?
text:
This has always been the case for me, not sure why, but when I have nothing to do at work I get very anxious.

I assume it’s because the other areas of my team are very busy and conversing on various problems and that makes me feel like dead weight and drains my energy.

Open to suggestions or tips on avoiding this. I’m trying to find things to do, but I find it equally draining to fill the time at work with useless stuff.

Ask HN: Potential cofounder is good match business-wise but not personality-wise
text:
I met a potential cofounder. He is the same age as me and we are both interested in building a startup in the same field. Our skillset also complement each other's. On the work-side of things, we are a solid match.

However our personalities are quite different. In other words, I wouldn't want to be friends with him or hang out with him as a friend. Actually come to think of it, he's not someone I want to sit next to for too long.

I figured that if I am to build a startup with someone, I could be sitting next to them 12 hours a day, every day, for many years to come. I have to enjoy or at least tolerate their company. At the same time, it's a rare opportunity to meet someone whose interests are very similar to mine with complementing skillsets.

I could keep looking for other cofounders, or I could try to see if I can learn to tolerate this potential cofounder. What would you do in this situation?
